hotspots.label: Frost Crystals
hotspots.fact: The sparkly ice crystals you see covering the hood of the car form when water vapor freezes directly into ice without becoming liquid water first. This process is called deposition and happens on cold winter mornings!

hotspots.label: Rising Sun
hotspots.fact: The bright sun low on the horizon tells us this photo was taken at sunrise or sunset. The sun's light bounces off the ice crystals, making them sparkle like tiny diamonds!

hotspots.label: Cold Surface
hotspots.fact: When moist air comes into contact with this very cold surface, the water molecules lose thermal energy rapidly and "lock" into a solid crystalline structure.  This is distinct from dew freezing; the sharp, feathery points indicate the ice grew directly from the air.

hotspots.label: Building Structure
hotspots.fact: The house in the background shows how frost affects our human environment too. Ice can form on roofs and windows, making buildings look beautiful but also requiring clearing for safety.
